title: vertical type. do's and dont's?
content:
hey guys  
i have always steered as far away from stacking type vertically, i have no memories of seeing it properly done. Now, at work, i have to do it for an interface, what rules should i observe?
author: isokon

comments.content: Basically, never ever stack it. Most likely you won't be using a fixed-width typeface, so the letters won't align at all, and readability will go right down the tubes. Set the text just as you would, then rotate it 90°… Which direction you choose to rotate it is more up to you, but generally, it looks better if the baseline is facing the edge of your interface.
Yes, a monospace face, capitals or unicase, such as [Panoptica](http://web.archive.org/web/20150426204508/http:/www.shinntype.com/panoptica.html) would cause the least problems.

There's a bakery in my neighborhood name of Schick's that has a sign set vertically:  
 S  
 C  
 H  
  I  
 K  
'S

Looks odd, but I guess someone had his heart set on that vertical sign.

—Joel
